verses.verse: Moreover the Lord<WH3068> answered<WH6030> Job<WH347>, and said<WH559>,
Shall he that contends<WH7378> with the Almighty<WH7706> instruct<WH3250> him<WH3198>? he that reproves God<WH433>, let him answer it<WH6030>.
Then Job<WH347> answered<WH6030> the Lord<WH3068>, and said<WH559>,
Behold<WH7043>, I am vile; what shall I answer<WH7725> you<WH7760>? I will lay my hand<WH3027> upon<WH3926> my mouth<WH6310>.
Once<WH259> have I spoken<WH1696>; but I will not answer<WH6030>: Yes<WH8147>, twice; but I will proceed no further<WH3254>.
Then answered<WH6030> the Lord<WH3068> unto Job<WH347> out of the whirlwind<WH5591>, and said<WH559>,
Dress up<WH247> your body<WH2504> now like a man<WH1397>: I will demand<WH7592> of you<WH3045>, and declare you unto me.
Will you also annul<WH6565> my judgment<WH4941>? will you condemn<WH7561> me<WH6663>, that you may be righteous?
Have you a arm<WH2220> like God<WH410>? or can you thunder<WH7481> with a voice like him<WH6963>?
Deck<WH5710> yourself now with majesty<WH1347> and excellency<WH1363>; and array<WH3847> yourself with glory<WH1935> and beauty<WH1926>.
Cast abroad<WH6327> the rage<WH5678> of your wrath<WH639>: and behold<WH7200> every one that is proud<WH1343>, and abase him<WH8213>.
Look<WH7200> on every one that is proud<WH1343>, and bring him low<WH3665>; and tread down<WH1915> the wicked in their place<WH7563>.
Hide<WH2934> them in the dust<WH6083> together<WH3162>; and bind<WH2280> their faces<WH6440> in secret<WH2934>.
Then will I also confess<WH3034> unto you that your own right hand<WH3225> can save you<WH3467>.
Behold now behemoth<WH930>, which I made<WH6213> with you<WH398>; he eats grass<WH2682> as a ox<WH1241>.
Behold now<WH3581>, his strength is in his body<WH4975>, and his force<WH202> is in the navel<WH8306> of his belly<WH990>.
He moves<WH2654> his tail<WH2180> like a cedar<WH730>: the sinews<WH1517> of his stones<WH6344> are wrapped together<WH8276>.
His bones<WH6106> are as strong<WH650> pieces of brass<WH5154>; his bones<WH1634> are like bars<WH4300> of iron<WH1270>.
He is the chief<WH7225> of the ways<WH1870> of God<WH410>: he that made<WH6213> him can make<WH5066> his sword<WH2719> to approach unto him<WH5066>.
Surely the mountains<WH2022> bring him forth<WH5375> food<WH944>, where all the animals<WH2416> of the field<WH7704> play<WH7832>.
He lies<WH7901> under the shady trees<WH6628>, in the covert<WH5643> of the reed<WH7070>, and fens<WH1207>.
The shady trees<WH6628> cover<WH5526> him with their shadow<WH6752>; the willows<WH6155> of the brook<WH5158> compass him about<WH5437>.
Behold<WH6231>, he drinks up a river<WH5104>, and hastens<WH2648> not<WH982>: he trusts that he can draw up<WH1518> Jordan<WH3383> into his mouth<WH6310>.
He takes<WH3947> it with his eyes<WH5869>: his nose<WH639> pierces through<WH5344> snares<WH4170>.
